newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINLAND SAYS RUSSIA HOLDS KEY TO EUROPE STABILITY.
newsitem.headline: FINLAND SAYS RUSSIA HOLDS KEY TO EUROPE STABILITY.

text.p: Economic progress in Russia and the emergence of a democratic system that its people can identify with and trust will be crucial for future stability in Europe, the Finnish government said on Tuesday.

In a report to the national parliament titled 'Finland and the future of Europe', the government said a desirable scenario for Europe's future would be marked by cooperation instead of confrontation and predictability instead of instability.
"Stability -- economic progress and consolidation of democratic practices -- in Russia is crucial to this end," the report said.
Finland took a decisive step by joining the EU in 1995.
While stressing that membership of the European Union was "the cornerstone of Finland's policy on Europe", the government dedicated a whole chapter of the report to the future of Russia.
"(Russia) is still essentially a European country oriented towards the West," Finland said, referring to the eastern neighbour with which it shares a 1,300 km (800 miles) border.
But Russia was in many ways different from other European countries, the Finnish government said, pointing at the concentration of economic and political power in the hands of elite groups.
The Russian political system -- apparently evolving towards a strong presidency and democratic procedures based on a market economy -- could pose problems in the future.

"Confinement of political influence to the elite is bound to increase citizen alienation and damage the legitimacy of the system," the report said, adding: "In unfavourable circumstances, this could foster instability."
"Growing income disparities, the sudden rise in mortality, crime ... and immesurably vast environmental problems are factors which may jeopardise the current favourable trend," it said.
The greatest challenge for Russian democracy was how to make citizens feel that the institutions of society are relevant.

"Russia has virtually no experience of a modern state or a democratic society ... By and large, the Soviet State was never based on the idea that people should feel that the system was 'their own'," the Finnish government noted.
Negative aspects of the current transition in Russia towards a capitalist market economy had impaired public faith in and respect for the political system, it said.
Unless Russian leaders came up with credible rules of the game, the outcome would be "value anarchy", Finland said.
It was important to turn traditionally strong Russian nationalism into a positive force.
"If the political system does not provide nationalism with a constructive outlet, it may be transformed and turn in an undesirable direction," the report said.
Great power status was important to Russian identity and NATO plans for eastward enlargement "have caused serious concern in Russia," Finland said.
Besides proposing alternative security policy solutions for Europe, Russia was seeking greater influence in CIS countries and Asia.
The latter "would certainly be reflected in a stronger position vis-a-vis the West," the Finnish government report said.
It said Russia was taking a favourable view of European Union enlargement.
"Eastward enlargement is a significantly more difficult issue for the EU than for the individual countries concerned," Finland said.
For the EU, the fundamental difficulty was the difference in standards of living between EU countries and East Europe's transition economies.
"The gulf in standards of living between Finland and its nearby regions is among the widest in Europe," the government said, referring to Russia and the Baltic republics.
"It is therefore among Finland's top priorities to narrow that gulf and promote stable, sustainable development in these regions," it said.
--Peter Starck, Helsinki Newsroom +358 - 0 - 680 50 245
